reasoning: [Specific Program Not Verified] Paper mentions 'Cash Waqf Linked Sukuk (CWLS) empowerment programs' but search could not confirm this as graduation program: Perplexity search result: The CWLS empowerment program in Indonesia is an Islamic social finance instrument designed to channel cash waqf via sukuk for social, educational, and poverty alleviation projects. The model does not follow the 'graduation' approach typical of BRAC-type ultra-poor livelihood programs, which deliver sequenced cash stipends, training, assets, and support for the ultra-poor with explicit evaluation toward graduation from poverty[1][5][3]. The evidence indicates CWLS primarily finances productive assets (e.g., infrastructure such as traditional markets for small traders, and education programs), but it does not appear to provide direct cash transfers/stipends to individuals for consumption as seen in graduation programs[1][4]. Proceeds from CWLS are used to build markets and provide low-rate financing to traders, rather than direct livelihood asset distributions. There is ambiguity around cash support: while Islamic banks may offer financing, it is asset-linked and not unconditional cash transfers. The program is primarily an asset/productive investment platform with strong financial inclusion and social investment goals, not a graduation model. | Graduation: NO, Cash: UNCLEAR, Assets: YES | Confidence: HIGH | Sources: https://rdis.seo.ir/media/ckeditor_files/2024/05/14/iman-sastra_p6PbKbO.pdf, https://uns.ac.id/en/bwi-national-seminar-encourages-uns-academic-community-to-join-indonesia-waqf-movement/, http://ur.aeu.edu.my/1197/1/Cash%20Waqf%20Linked%20Sukuk%20(CWLS)%20Returns%20and%20Social%20Programs%20in%20Indonesia.pdf
verified_program_name: Cash Waqf Linked Sukuk (CWLS) empowerment programs
